docs.lead_paragraph: AS president of the Manhattan-based Medicare Rights Center, Diane Archer travels around the country as a spokeswoman and omsbudswoman for older adults and the disabled. Her main concern is that as health costs soar and Medicare payments lag, retired people now spend 19 percent of their income, on average, for items, like drugs, that are not covered by Medicare. The nonprofit center, which she helped start 10 years ago, fielded 57,000 calls seeking help last year. On recent business trips, she has met with retired government workers in Wenatchee, Wash., state and local Medicare experts in Cincinnati and consumer education colleagues in the nation's capital.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Safeco Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the United States group life insurance and medical insurance business of ING Groep N.V. for $34.8 million. Safeco will acquire ING's Atlanta-based Medical Risk Solutions unit, which helps employers cover unexpected health-care costs. The Seattle-based company said it expected to complete the purchase by year-end. ING is the biggest financial-services company in the Netherlands. The purchase adds to Safeco's 25-year-old medical excess loss business. The insurer sells life, home and auto insurance, and coverage for corporate customers.

headline.main: SAFECO TO PURCHASE MEDICAL INSURANCE CONCERN

docs.lead_paragraph: Prices at the producer level shot up 1.1 percent in September, the biggest monthly increase in nine years, the Government reported today. The report stoked fears among investors that inflation might be accelerating and helped to set off a wave of selling on Wall Street, which was already jittery over comments on Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, about the difficulty of determining whether stock prices are too high.

headline.main: Producer Prices Show Gain of 1.1 Percent, Biggest in Nine Years

docs.snippet: Prices at the producer level shot up 1.1 percent in September, the biggest monthly increase in nine years, the Government reported today.    The report stoked fears among investors that inflation might be accelerating and helped to set off a wave of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The growth of managed-care health plans since the mid-1990's brought the explosive rise of health-care costs to at least a temporary halt. But cost control antagonized both physicians and patients. Physicians choked on constraints that insurance companies slapped on their income and professional autonomy. Patients complained that denials by H.M.O.'s of treatments recommended by physicians amounted to profit-driven betrayal. But now comes evidence that managed-care systems are bending to satisfy both patients and doctors with modifications in at least one key area, payments to physicians. The modifications have come from some of the more venturesome Independent Practice Associations, known as I.P.A.'s, which are groups of doctors that sign contracts with H.M.O.'s to treat enrollees. In many Western states such groups treat most of the enrollees in H.M.O.'s, and they are growing everywhere else, including New York City.

docs.lead_paragraph: HER name is not as important as her unhappy past, which comes back to stalk her every now and then. What you need to know is that she was once a young woman in Poland, and, being a Jew, she had to flee when the Germans invaded in 1939. But there was no refuge in the Polish countryside, not for her. She spent the next years as a slave laborer in a series of factories in Germany and Poland. The end of World War II found her in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. Later, she made her way to America and, ultimately, the Lower East Side.

headline.main: For Survivor Of Holocaust, Another Test

docs.abstract: Clyde Haberman, in NYC column, describes how anonymous survivor of Holocaust, woman in her 80's living on Lower East Side, has been traumatized by questionnaire that she must complete by Oct 22 so she can assert her claim to compensation from $1.25 billion fund that Swiss banks propose to create (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-23 Clinton Chastises Senate For Rejecting Treaty President Clinton accused the Republicans who defeated a treaty banning underground nuclear testing of retreating into a new isolationism that threatened national security. He pledged to abide by the treaty's provisions and warned countries with nuclear ambitions not to test. A1 Foreign leaders and arms experts reacted with dismay and anger to the Senate action. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Citing a continued rise in the number of Americans without health coverage, Hillary Rodham Clinton today called for ''quality, affordable health insurance for everyone in the country,'' saying it would be a mistake to abandon the goal because of her failed effort to change the system six years ago. The First Lady, in back-to-back speeches on health care, also sharply criticized Medicare cuts that had been embraced by President Clinton to balance the budget in 1997, saying they had proved damaging to hospitals, particularly in New York. ''These cuts went too far,'' Mrs. Clinton declared. ''They have caused too much pain and are cutting into too much muscle and bone.''

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Renews Fight For Universal Health Care

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, citing continued rise in number of Americans without health coverage, calls for 'quality, affordable health insurance for everyone in the country'; criticizes Medicare cuts that had been embraced by Pres Clinton to balance budget in 1997; her remarks, made during trip across Adirondack region, offer first glimpse into how she intends to make health care central subject of her expected campaign for US Senate; photo (M)
